title: Pep Guardiola was so angry about Man City's loss to Liverpool he was punching things AN HOUR later
text:
Sport Pep Guardiola was so angry about Man City's loss to Liverpool he was punching things AN HOUR later The Blues' frustrated boss was seen in animated conversation with director of football Txiki Begiristain after a defeat that puts them 10 points behind leaders Chelsea Share City star Yaya Toure confirmed the performance at Anfield had Guardiola fuming (Photo: Reuters) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! The picture of Pep Guardiola furiously slapping his fist into his palm an hour after the final whistle, told the most poignant story of Manchester City 's loss at Liverpool. 
City manager Guardiola was animatedly engaged in conversation with his director of football and close ally Txiki Begiristain, and was clearly making an angry point about a lack of aggression in his Blues side. 
He repeatedly pounded one hand into the other, and then opened his arms wide in exasperated questioning of their approach – which confirmed the admission made by Blues star Yaya Toure after an embarrassing defeat by a superior team. 
“Of course the manager was angry at half-time. When you are losing and Liverpool are the better side, when you are losing like that then it’s not going to be happy at half-time. It was disappointing and we all felt that,” he admitted. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Pep Guardiola reacts to defeat to Liverpool Share this video Watch Next 
“Of course he is going to be angry. He is a manager who can be angry. We have to sometimes improve and react to situations, so he will be angry for everything is happening.” 
Liverpool dominated the first half, scored a brilliant early goal when Georginio Wijnaldum brilliantly converted Adam Lallana’s cross after a flowing move, and then controlled superbly the inevitable second half fightback. 
Clearly, that left the Spanish coach wondering about the mental strength of his team, and their ability to adopt the aggressive, pressing game he employed at Barca and Bayern, and which his rival Jurgen Klopp has humming at Anfield. Guardiola dominated in Spain and Germany but English football has him scratching his head (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) 
Toure himself was one of the main culprits, appearing listless and lacking in imagination, as the visitors failed to convert almost total second half possession in a single serious chance. 
It leaves the City manager wondering when he can convert this team to his style – and no doubt plotting some serious surgery in the January transfer window with Southampton defender Virgil van Dijk a live target – but Toure believes the Blues will take their manager’s anger and turn it into inspiration. 
“We have to recognise that Liverpool played well and deserved the three points, but we can learn from this and what the manager says about it,” he added. Southampton defender Van Dijk is one player on City's January transfer radar (Photo: Getty) 
“I think you have to ask him what he said. 
"When you lose games though, what do you have to do? You are disappointed, and you want to bounce back. We don’t want to let the gap grow much more between us and Liverpool, Arsenal and Tottenham. So we have to react. 
“We will use it – we are not going to give up. We will go to the end. 
"We have to believe we can win the title – and in football, anything is possible.” 
While City are clinging on to faint hope, Saturday's game showed Liverpool as the most obvious challenge to Chelsea’s dominance at the head of the table, and Wijnaldum is ready to help fire them there. Wijnaldum's soaring header finished off a sweeping move for the only goal (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) 
His headed goal was perfect – an embodiment of desire – even though it was only the second time he's scored this season. 
At the start of the campaign, after his summer move from Newcastle, the Dutch midfielder insisted he must get into double figures. And even though he’s been playing in a much deeper position, argued that is still possible. 
“This is a different way of playing from my previous club but still I think I will reach that number. I’ll do everything but the most important thing is we win games,” he said. 
“If I can help with my goals even better for me and the team but if I don’t score and play a good game I am still happy. But I still think I can score 10 goals this season.” poll loading Where will Manchester City finish this season? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
